response.answer_text: I don’t consider myself to be really materialistic. Whenever I spend money on something, it always has some degree of utility or convenience that justifies the cost of paying for it. For example, I am on track to purchase more cell phones in a single year than I have owned in all previous years of my life combined. Next year, I might also do the same with laptops and desktops if the funds are there. There’s actually a good reason for doing so. The first reason would be that I needed phones with the longest battery lifespans/capacity. So I bought one phone and locked it to one of my hometown’s carriers (which at the time had the best plans and prices). Now that their competitor is offering better plans (for some cases which will make economic sense), I needed another phone with an even longer battery life which would work on their LTE band (which my other phone can’t work on even if I got it unlocked). I’m also now in the business of developing my own mobile apps and testing them out on different platforms that my customers will be using. So I purchased other phones with different operating systems like iOS and Ubuntu Touch. That’s 4 phones in one year, two of which are for personal use and another two which are for testing apps. They’re not insanely expensive stuff though. They’re the cheapest models with all the minimum features I need for the purpose which they were purchased for. Here are some other things I’d do if I had the money: If I were to buy a car (with money not being an issue), I’d purchase a Volkswagen XL1 for environmental reasons and not because it’s insanely expensive.As for owning a house, well I’d try to make it as small as possible and I’d build it to be as strong, low-maintenance and energy-efficient as possible. That will cost a bit extra, but it will be worth it in my opinion.I’d also hire one or several people to do all my chores, run minor errands, cook and drive me around, etc. So that way, I could focus more on my work and ideas.I’d buy that Tempur Pedic mattress.I’d fly coach on short trips and only use business or first class on extremely long trips (exceeding 10 hours) where I’m expected to sleep on the plane overnight. I’d only use private charters if I needed to access a remote or inaccessible location for a really good reason.For hotels, my standards remain the same. I’ll stay pretty much anywhere as long as I have reliable power, running water, adequate heating/cooling, no bedbugs, no rusty fixtures etc. If the place is cheap enough, I might not mind if the wifi sucks. I’ll just get an unlimited 4G mobile plan for the week or month with some of the money I’d save from staying at that hotel (as opposed to one of the more expensive ones). I actually did this on one of my recent work-related trips.Essentially, every dollar I spend will have some degree of justifiable convenience or utility. I’ll never purchase something frivolously for the sake of purchasing it to impress others or whatnot. I don’t pander to shallowness nor avarice. I also don’t judge people by what material possessions they have or don’t have.

I definitely have expensive tastes. I cheer myself up during tedious hours in hospitals by scrolling down Violet Grey and The Line, ogling hundred-dollar bath oils and inordinately expensive bath salts that’s inordinately expensive because apparently they smell like rotenburo air. I roll my eyes whenever someone on reddit bashes Tatcha oil cleanser with the “there are sooo many other cheaper products, like this and that and so and so and as a wise person you should definitely buy the cheaper one” argument and inwardly scream how they are just not the same, duh I clip and save pictures of beautiful homes and expensive makeup and dresses and when my parents one day make me have a big Chinese wedding, I can’t say there isn’t a part of me that itches for a swarovski clad wedding ball gown. But what’s weird is that I’m actually really relaxed about money. It’s the least of my considerations. The numbers are just not that important to me. I make quite a lot of money now, at least way more than I actually need, and although I get that exhilarating “ka-ching!” sensation every time I tab my earnings, it just… isn’t that interesting to me. I’ve been trying to adult and ask my brother things about wise budgeting and investment practices; but while all the money multiplying and filling portfolios excites him, it doesn’t really do that for me. I dated a person way more financially challenged than me for years, and his financial difficulties never mattered for one second. I don’t actually mind living frugally and considered that back when I still thought of settling down with him. I don’t know- I guess I’m as relaxed about money getting in as much as money getting out. I don’t really care how much money I get, and when I do have money I can be a generous spender, but when I don’t have money, then well I don’t mind it all that much. I UNDERSTAND ALL THIS IS SO UN-ADULT And I’ll try to do better and actually comprehend the value of money. But it’s just something that feels utterly foreign to me, something I don’t enjoy at all.

I would say I’m pretty prudent when it comes to materialism. I don’t cherish things for the sake of having them, but I do appreciate quality where relevant. For example, my work bag. I went through several backpacks as a middle and high-schooler because they would just get work out with all the books and the load on the bag and straps day to day. You could rely on a bag lasting maybe 2 years. Then came work. I needed a bag to put my stuff in . I got a targus shoulder bag. “Whatever, its functional and in my budget and is pretty non-descript. I’m not trying to make a fashion statement.” I went through three of those in about 8 years. After the get worn out, but are still working they look sort of sad and don’t make the best impression if you are walking into a meeting from the airport. So, I decided I wanted to buy one more bag. One that was functional, was still understated, but would still look professional. I also wanted it to not look sad as it aged, but age appropriately, and would age over the next 30–40 years of my career. It turns out those kinds of bags are expensive. REALLY expensive. I decided leather was the only option. Tumi’s ballistic material even wears out (but I hear the have a good repair policy) and leather would also have a little more personality than black ballistic material. So, I picked out a bag. the exact bag, with the exact color and size and put it on my wish list. My parents got it for me as my b-school graduation present. It continues to be the perfect bag going on 2 years. I take care of it. It takes care of me, and should for the rest of my life, as long as I don’t loose it. Now, the wishlist. I have a set of items I have identified as “last purchases” this includes things like a backpacking bag, a pair of black dress shoes (not for every day work wear), etc. Things I can invest in, will reliably do what they are supposed to do as long as I take care of it. This list isn’t necessarily all premium items. For example, for our new car, we bought a used Subaru Forester. 2 years old. its an incredibly reliable car and should be in shape to give to our son in 16 years if we take care of it. Something every new driver should have - a well-used, reliable, safe car that doesn’t scream “my daddy got me a BMW - look at me!” So yeah, I’m materialistic, but in the value sense of the material goods. I hate cheaply made stuff that I will just have to continue to replace at annoyingly short intervals.

I’m rather collectivist when it comes to standard of living so it’s hard to say how materialistic I am. I don’t care much about having my own personal possessions that increase my quality of life, such as a large house or a car, I’d rather live in an environment that offers a good standard of living - I am a very urban person, I like living fairly centrally in a city with top-notch public transport, with a lot of culture, amenities, free wi-fi, a good cycling infrastructure, good maintenance of the city infrastructure, parks, festivals, a well-equipped public library, walkable distances etc. Living in such a city is expensive in itself, so it’s not like the lifestyle I aspire is something anyone could easily afford, but you still don’t own a lot in terms of material possessions, I would rather have the community offer such a good quality of life that it’s rather expensive to be even able to even participate in the community so you don’t even need a lot of possessions on your own. I’d rather pay a a lot of taxes and pay a fairly high rent to live in an apartment that’s just large enough for me to live fairly comfortably (say, about 40m²) if I benefit from living in a community with a high standard of living and a lot of services that make your life more comfortable. I do enjoy some activities that cost money, such as traveling or skiing. I would like to own a real piano some day. I think I’m willing to spend some money on an expensive bed, mattresses and pillows because a good night’s sleep makes such an important difference. Sometimes I like to cook with somewhat fancy ingredients and I buy a lot of books and occasionally I’ll buy a video game. I’ve always traveled very low-budget and low-comfort, both in terms of means of transport and in terms of accomodation, and the reason was mostly that I could never afford anything else, but to be honest, it never bothered me all that much and I’m not sure I’d spend more money on this if I had more disposable income. Even when I slept in a crappy bunk bed in a hostel with 11 strangers in the same room, I rarely felt a desperate wish to have more money so I could finally upgrade my traveling. Sometimes I even consider it a fun challenge to find cheap deals and clever traveling hacks for low-budget traveling. But maybe this will change as I get older and have less tolerance for low-comfort services. On the other hand, I’ve always felt very limited in the possible destinations - I could just never afford to travel outside Europe, so with more disposable income I’d definitely embrace the opportunity to travel the world. But: I am very proud of being one of only 100,000 people in the world who own a copy of the limited collector’s edition of The Tales of Beedle the Bard that was sold on Amazon back in 2008 and all copies were sold after a few hours and I was fast enough to buy one for what was a fortune to me. This is the snobbiest, most materialistic thing I’ve done in my life, I guess. A few years ago when I was a tourist in Amsterdam I met another tourist from Ireland who also owned a copy and I instantly bonded with her over this :)

Most of those who have read my answers on Quora will think I am. But I’m mostly not. For a start, my goal is to die penniless. I want to have spent all my money in impacting humanity in a positive way before I die. I’m not saying I’ll accomplish my goal - I doubt I will - because of greed. Letting go of money is never easy. But at least I have it as a goal. Further, I don’t want anything more, materially. I only want to keep 5 things I already have… A 7.5k sq.ft. penthouse with its own swimming pool. It’s the best home for me, balancing facilities, security, an incredible view, location, etc… that I have ever seen. Anything bigger would lose family intimacy. I work from here often, my kids don’t go to school, we have a BBQ every week, I swim every morning, so it’s a luxury I really take advantage of. Here’s the living room… A decent motor. In Malaysia, that means US$150k for a new one every 6–8 years. My wife is perhaps the least materialistic person I’ve ever met - she refuses to let me buy her a car for over $30k and won’t change it until it’s destroyed.Business class flights.3 or 4 trips every year to five-star beach resorts in Malaysia with my family. We all work hard. That’s how we chill.Generally have enough to spend, but nothing extravagant. A MacBook every couple of years, clothes from the likes of Gap or Gant, eat out at decent but not posh restaurants, etc…It is materialistic of me that I wanted the above 5 a lot. But it’s certainly not beyond what most would expect of me. I don’t want a yacht, holiday homes, more than one car at a time, fancy food, expensive watches, an Ambani home. And I might be giving up the motor, reducing the list to 4, if Uber can reduce the waiting times. I really aspire to live a simple life, I want to free myself from material wants. Giving up a car would be a big one for me as I’ve always loved cars. I have this huge conflict in my head. Between what I do and what I know is right. Finally, and I feel this is important in answering the question, I am very conscious of the fact that I’m going to be dead soon (<60 years) and it will all go. I realise, and more consciously than most, it’s all kind of meaningless. So am I materialistic? Yes, I am. But I feel I’m mostly not. Perhaps I think too much… [BTW if I give anything to charity, and I’m not saying I do, I’m not open to discussing it!]

I thought it was bad to have a lot of money, until someone reminded me that with a lot of money I could do a lot of good, and that was what the concept of the Benevolent Jew was all about. It’s good to have money because it helps you do good for the community and charities. (Of course you can help with time and skill as well.) I also discovered that having a lot of money did not equal being materialistic. I had not separated the concepts in my mind, leaving them both rather murky. I also had to tease apart the idea that you could do important things without money, with the reality that money makes important things easier to do. I did most of the things I’ve done in my life with very little money. I’m not materialistic - owning things doesn’t mean all that much to me, although there are a few things that are important to me to have. I do like more money than not, though. I like the ability to do more good than my time and skill alone can.

Habib Fanny A2A'd me this. Good thing he requested this answer to everyone, otherwise I'll be astounded how fast he sees right through me. I'm materialistic enough to make career plans according to the monetary compensation, but not yet materialistic enough to date a person merely for the money. Here is what I, a professional cynic, think about money. Hell, a professor once said I was the No.1 cynic in the entire school. I'm not always so materialistic though. I was very idealistic before I left college. I dreamed of changing the world. After I graduated, I found I actually couldn't even change my balance in my banking account, I couldn't afford to see a doctor and I had to think twice before buying a yogurt. This kind of life sucks. Therefore, money is the No.1 thing that would provide me with a sense of security. A strong sense of security. Nothing else. I don't really believe in love or friendship, especially in the adult world at workplace where money is involved. I enjoy buying stuff, especially when I'm stressed out. I resort to retail therapy. Sadly,I can't afford much right now and my bank account balance stresses me out the most. I enjoy buying stuff and paying for dinner for my significant other. My life long dream is to hand over my credit card and tell my SO “Buy whatever you want. The PIN code is 1234.”/ I don't have luxurious hobbies though, but I guess it doesn't hurt to pick up one or two like golf or photography. I long for a materialistically wealthy life, with an apartment on the top floor of a skyscraper in the center of Chicago or Manhattan, a maid to regularly clean the apartment for me, nice furniture, a large TV and acoustic instruments for watching horror movies. Besides, in today's world, having a lot of money means you're successful, and others look up to successful people. If you want your voice to be heard and you want people to take you seriously, be what they consider as successful first. Otherwise, why would they bother to talk to you? At the end of the day, building relationship in the adult world is all about transaction. You have something I want, and I offer something in return. That being said, I actually do have some pursuit outside of money. I want to be an LGBT advocate and a public defender at a state government, neither of which pays well. But I'm doing everything I can to prepare for it, in case opportunity shows up. My theory is — earn money and consolidate your position in the society first, get some savings and then you can do whatever you like! Besides, it's a terrible idea to make what you like as your first job because your passion would burn out fast during the process of adapting to the professional world and day-to-day grinding over the desk. Yeah, overall I'm a very shallow person. People usually would be surprised by how materialistic I am, given that I have three academic degrees at a young age. Well, I did that because Asians tend to look up to people graduated from fancy schools in the US, and partly because my parents required me to. Hell, I think this answer sounds extremely obnoxious.

Yes i am. I love material possessions. Actually, my dog Rummy does more. Like this expensive toy he adores.  He can try his might but he can't destroy it. And if you did not know, Rottweilers have the highest bite force of any dog breed.  But it doesn't end there. I have to buy him more of those to satisfy his materialistic needs.  See the tail wag in the above picture? It's disgusting. He does tell me he loves those toys and wants more of them.  And i have to oblige. Materialism is addictive you know.  And that's not all. He will play with a goddamn table lamp if he fancies that.  There's no end to these materialistic pursuits. Like how he recently coaxed me into buying him shoes.  Come on now. Really? Now dogs want to be sneakerheads? Here's the truth. His feet have chronic infection. It's right under his paws actually. That means it's terribly painful for him to walk when the infection flares up. It's straight up bleeding. He lies on the floor a full day or two, when the infection is real bad. I've tried multiple vets and the vets have tried all sorts of medicines. Blood tests, x-rays, injections. The infection is persistent. It can be controlled and managed, but it hasn't gone away, yet. The shoes protect his feet from bleeding. These materialistic things provide him relief. They enable his walks, and he loves walks. His collection of toys keeps him busy and entertained. Dogs and kids are alike. They get bored easy. And they love their toys. You see, being materialistic is judged in today's world. Spirituality is overrated. The fact is, human beings have been materialistic from the very beginning. Tools, ornaments, totems, better homes, vehicles, thrones — the list is endless. Material possessions help elevate our life experiences, if we know what we're doing. The trick is to maintain balance and not lose track of the raw natural world. Rummy loves his friends as much as his toys, maybe even more.    There have been times when he clearly communicated to me he wants to spend the night outside. He hangs out with his street buddies and returns home at 3am or 4am, and bangs on the gates. I let him in. I'm happy he knows his priorities in life. On a side note, his materialism has reached a point where he thinks every Amazon package is just for him.  As for me, i love being able to buy the cameras and phones that help me capture these memories. And share them. I also love walking into the store to buy biscuits for my other friends.

I would say no, but to some extent I am, despite my claim to the contrary. There are varying degrees of materialism. On one end of the spectrum are those whose identities are wrapped up in their possessions. They are constantly looking to acquire more so as to validate themselves and keep up with others they view as competitors. Rich or poor. Towards the other end are people who own nothing whatsoever. Perhaps not even their freedom. Residing on this end of the spectrum does not disqualify you from being materialistic. These individuals may greatly desire material goods. Their situation makes it difficult to acquire them though. Also at this extreme are people who have nothing and do not want anything. They’re perfectly happy living this way, seeing no need to buy things they have no use for. In my case, I don’t want to have many possessions, but I have far more than most. What I do have is what I need and use on a regular basis. It’s not wrong to be on one end or the other. Owning stuff isn’t a problem in and of itself. The problem arises when people become overly attached. More value is placed on these possessions than on actual people. What’s worrying is this trend appears to be on the rise and is unlikely to be going anywhere in the near future.

I don’t really consider myself terribly materialistic. A lot of the things people get with their money and wealth just kind of elude me. I don’t give a shit about having a nice car. If it gets me reliably from Point A to Point B, that’s good enough for me. I don’t care if it’s a Porsche 911, or a Geo Metro. I don’t give a shit about having a big house. I live in a basement suite with my wife. It’s a bit tight, but I’m perfectly fine with it. Could probably use a bit more storage space, but I definitely don’t need a gigantic house, and will never own one regardless of how much money I make. Same with other shit like big screen TVs, or nice watches, or whatever. The only possession I have I spend decent money on is my PC. I’m a big gamer, and so I invest in a nice PC to play those games. If I won the lottery, I’d buy the best PC I could, and likely put the rest away in savings. That would be my ‘splurge.’ What I do care about is financial stress. I want to make more money not so I can buy really big and awesome possessions, but so I can stop worrying about money. I hate worrying whether or not we can afford to buy all our groceries. I hate seeing half my paycheque disappear instantly paying student loans. I hate knowing that my car needs repairs, but I can’t afford them, and have to live in worry that it’s going to break down at some point and I won’t be able to get to work. I hate being completely unable to put away a single dime towards savings. So I don’t consider myself materialistic, not in the usual sense of wanting all sorts of fancy things. I want money to be free of financial stress and worry, not to get the latest iPhone.

Hell yes! Everyone is. This is just one of those taboos where you feel good by convincing yourself that renouncing materialistic pleasure is a desirable trait. I am a nature fanatic. Does that mean I am not materialistic? No it doesn’t. If I am a nature lover, I want a house at the beach, on the mountains, a tree house, a camp in the desert, and even an underwater house if possible. I want to have a place where I can peacefully retire in solitude after a stressful week. Unfortunately, I am not a saint, and just forests don’t work for me. I like forests, but then, I don’t want to lose out on the facilities I have in the city. At the end of the day, you need to buy things. You need money, home, cars, clothes, shoes, watches and what not. “Roti, kapda, makaan” is a bare necessity, not a satisfactory state of fulfillment. I have not met any person who is not materialistic in the 21 years I have spent in this world. People are materialistic about different things. Some dream about fashion, some about tech, some about cars, some about plain wealth. But everyone dreams to achieve something materialistic, and that is what keeps us going. This very trait is what drives the develooment of humans. Just imagine, if everyone was satisfied on the earth, how would it look like?

Yes. Most definitely, I am extremely materialistic, and it’s a character flaw I need to work on. I like having money, I like seeing a large balance in my checking account, I like investing. I like building assets, I like reading about investing, I like saving money. I remember having this be a major problem. As a little kid, I remember the teacher telling us the legend of Hannah and her Seven Sons. “Now, girls, would you pick God or a roomful of toys?” the teacher asked. I raised my hands. “I want the toys.” And I did. God didn’t matter anything to me. Everyone else seemed to want to sacrifice, and I just wanted those toys. I got teased for that. When I was in 7th grade, we were told that a great rabbi could have gone into business, but chose a life of community supported scholarship instead. And I argued that made him a leech on society, since he was dependant on others for support, and that money was all that was mattered. “If you are relying on my tax dollars to find God, you’re not much of a person,” I said. My teacher asked me what money would do in the World to Come. I asked her what the World to Come had to do with not starving to death. She sent me to the principal, who let me sit and study in the library. I’m very into the material, even if I appreciate the more ephemeral today. One of my motivational quotes is this. “If you wrote something for which someone sent you a check, if you cashed the check and it didn't bounce, and if you then paid the light bill with the money, I consider you talented.”― Stephen King AKA, if you can’t produce some sort of material value with it….you need to examine the value. Now, it still might be worth it, but you do need to check.

A few years ago, my mother broke her back and had to be operated. It was a major surgery on her spine and lucky for us, I had a job and all three of us were adequately insured by my then employer. Had it not been for that coverage, we would have gone bonkers and I would have been writing an answer on how to deal with personal debts. I’m materialistic to an extent where I need loads of money, money that I can pull out any time to provide best-in-class healthcare to my aging uglies, without having to worry about making a huge dent on my personal savings.I vividly remember what it was like to be poor - less food, sometimes no food, improper medical treatments at government hospitals that possibly fucked up my hearing, quarrels, more quarrels and so on, so obviously I’ve grown more materialistic than someone who grew up in a middle class family. I would like my parents to have a comfortable life. Not a beach house or a farm house or an island of that sort, and they wouldn’t like all that anyway, but a nice house with an open balcony and a cozy swing which my father can use to sit and read his morning and evening papers, while my mother serves him his hot tea and sits aside to catch up on daily gossips.We currently own a hatchback. A tiny one at that. The lowest possible model in the entire range sort of thing. That’s what we could afford. In all honesty, that’s what the bank actually approved of. Though I have now closed the loan entirely a couple years back, every time I or someone else makes as tiny a scratch as possible, my heart rips out of my chest and cries. Because ONLY I know how much blood and sweat went into buying this thing. I’m materialistic to a point where I want to be able to afford repairs or worse case, replace this tiny one with another tiny one without as much as batting an eye.I don’t like swanky shit. I’m not a traveler. All the cool things people do these days, I don’t think its for me. I don’t want to be a vagabond or something of that sort roaming from one place to another. I’m glad for people who like it, but no, its just not for me. I don’t want to bungee jump from Macau Tower or ski in Switzerland. I don’t even like cold weather. I’m currently working on my Table Tennis topspins and I spend about 2000 Rupees (around $30) a month on my coaching and I’m very happy with what I currently do. But, I want to be able to afford a nice holiday even if I really don’t want to travel anywhere. The feeling that I can but I don’t want to, is always better than, I can’t but I don’t want to either. You get me?My family prospers only because of the education we had. If with so little opportunities provided to us having been born in a poor family from a developing country, we could come thus far and become something of substance, I wonder what we could do if we receive the best in class education from a developed nation such the USA. And I want to be able to afford THAT! And that without having to beg or rob our banks here. I think that’s as materialistic as I can get.

I go through phases. As a child and teen, I was pretty frugal and liked to save money. It helped that I wasn’t particularly into clothes and my parents bought me the necessities. I did buy a car in high school, but I saved up and paid cash. My mom paid the insurance. I sold it during my freshman year of university. In college I started to get more interested in clothes, accessories and electronics. I bought a Macbook and a pair of Uggs (don’t judge, they were all the rage at the University of Oregon in the early 2010s). But generally, I didn’t have much money left over after paying for living expenses. I got my first “adult” job in March 2014. My husband’s freelance business took off around the same time. That was the first time in my life that I had significant disposable income (although not as much as I had expected). Luckily, we didn’t go crazy. We stuck with sensible cars (Kia Rios) and paid them both off. We didn’t buy a bunch of liabilities. We paid down my student loans. But we did move into a very nice two-bedroom townhouse and spend a couple thousand on furniture. We had this enormous cream-colored sectional sofa that was amazing to lounge on. We took a few short but expensive vacations. I would go shopping a lot on the weekends. Partly because I didn’t want to keep wearing my high school and college clothes, but mostly because I was stressed. The pressure from my job followed me into the weekends. I couldn’t stop thinking about this or that project. So I made a lot of small compensatory purchases to make myself feel better. That, of course, didn’t work. By 24 I was in the grips of a full-blown quarter-life crisis. I had the whole package—a college degree, a good job in my field (not easy for a languages major), a happy marriage, a beautiful home, the latest iPhone, 15 days of paid vacation a year and a higher income than my parents had ever earned. And I was constantly anxious and miserable. I felt trapped in a cycle of working and spending. It was as if someone else had planned out my life for me when I wasn’t looking. The apartment, the furniture, the new clothes no longer brought me any pleasure. They felt like chains that kept me bound to a job I had come to hate. We messed up our taxes and wrote a $6000 check to the IRS. We got into a dispute with the manager of our fancy apartment complex. I couldn’t quit my job—the rent was too high. My job and lifestyle were eating me alive. I started feeling sick and panicky on Sunday nights. By fall of 2015, I knew something had to change. My husband and I came up with a plan—I’d apply to a teaching assistantship in France, he’d apply to grad school in Ohio. We both got accepted and started planning our big move East in summer 2016. That was my anti-materialistic phase. We could only take what would fit in the Kias, so I started getting rid of All The Things. I watched minimalism videos on YouTube. I used the KonMari method of decluttering (from the Japanese book The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up). Marie Kondo suggests holding every possession in your hands and getting rid of any that don’t “spark joy”. So that’s what I did. I gave away half my clothes and piles of random things from around the house. It was liberating. I wanted time and experiences, not a 9-to-6 and stuff. (For the record—there are a few select items I wish I’d kept, like my turtleneck shirt and snow pants. But I cannot remember most of the stuff I gave away.) Almost two years later, I’ve moderated a little bit. I never buy things just for the sake of shopping and I still value experiences over things, but I do get new clothes and household items from time to time. We’re planning on buying a condo early next year. But we still drive the Kias, and we paid cash for our older iPhones. I’m really grateful that we didn’t buy any big money pits during our materialistic phase. It was hard enough to escape the work-and-consume cycle as it was. I’m much, much happier now that I have ample free time and can set my own work schedule. I might get more materialistic in the future, but only if I could easily afford it without going back to a cubicle farm. Even then, I would only buy stuff to add joy to my life, not to create a “lifestyle” to impress people I don’t like. My quarter-life crisis taught me that consumption doesn’t lead to happiness. Anyone who tells you it does is probably trying to sell you something.

Like many, I try to make as much money as possible and spend the least amount as I can, but RARELY at the expense of comfort. Although, I don’t confuse comfort with overkill. And that means that I tend to go to great lengths to get the best stuff at the cheapest price—which often ends up actually being free. My main computer, for example, was fished out of the local electronics dumpster. That’s not to say that it’s bad in any way, however. After I cleaned it up, wiped the hard drive, and essentially refurbished the laptop, it is now the fastest computer I currently have. How fast, you ask? I can run a DAW, Google Chrome, MS Outlook, UTAU, Discord, and run a system scan all at the same time, and nothing lags. And I got it for free! Out of a fucking dumpster!I’d say it’s worth around $250 today, but I got it for free.My monitor is the same deal. I fished it out of the same electronics dumpster, and even thought the aspect ratio is a perfect square (and it also doesn’t have a logo anywhere that tells me who manufactured it), it has worked quite well up to this point. The resolution isn’t particularly impressive, but I don’t really do anything that really requires high resolution anyway.I’d say it’s worth around $50 today, but I got it for free.The phone that I currently use piggybacks off of my family’s plan that we’ve had since last year, so my parents are paying for it. The plan lasts until Summer of next year, so until then, I can use unlimited calling/text/data for free (on my part, at least). It’s also a pretty high-end phone, so I haven’t the need to switch phones anytime soon.$188 per month. I have it for free.I currently live in an apartment with a roommate, and it was my genius idea to split the rent by how many square footage we claim for ourselves. Since I chose the guest bedroom as my room, as well as the attached bath, I only have to pay about a quarter of the rent—my roommate pays everything else, as he’s the only one who uses the living room, nook, kitchen, master bed/bath.$2,440 per month. I pay $650. Don’t worry, my roommate is totally chill with it. He makes a far better income than I do anyway.I don’t have a mattress; I sleep on foldable tatami mats that sit right atop the wood floors. However, this decision to sleep on tatami mats instead of a mattress was not to save money—it was because I liked it.Average price for a good mattress: around $1500. I use tatami mats for $200.My pillow is probably in the top 10 most expensive things that I’ve ever bought. It’s a $1000 Sleep Number pillow. The issue with most pillows I’ve had is that, after sleeping on it for a while, it molds into a permanent shape that becomes very uncomfortable, and must be replaced. So I figured that buying an expensive high-tech pillow that doesn’t lose its shape, lasts for a lifetime, and comes with benefits like natural thermal management, was a much better investment than having to buy a new cheap pillow every few months.Even though its initial price was around $1000, I bought it during a Christmas sale, which bumped it down to around $900, and since I was a new customer, they discounted further down to $850. Through some negotiation with the saleswoman, I only had to pay around $810.I’ve got one blanket and a duvet, both of which are silk. I didn’t buy any of them—they were gifts from a family-owned bedding shop in Taiwan that had very good ties with my grandparents. They’re extremely high quality, and I’ve been told that they would normally be worth several thousand USD.Initial price: $1500+ EACH. I got them for free.My daily driver is a used 2010 Lexus RX, which I got for just a hair under $13,000 because its previous owner was our neighbour when I still lived with my parents. And even though it’s not terribly quick, sporty, or high-tech by today’s standards, it’s still a damn good car. Most of the leather has been preserved because its previous owners used cloth seat covers, and it’s quite comfy. Even though it hasn’t got the Mark Levinson sound system upgrades, it is still better than any audio device I currently own. The car hasn’t needed a single repair every since it was bought, which is nice.Average price today: around $18,000. Saved $5,000.As for most other necessities, I purchase them from MUJI. It’s got unique and high quality items at a more-than-reasonable price.Of course, I could solve most of these problems by landing a job that pays A LOT more than what I currently make, that would demand more of me, but it would infringe on my comfort. Right now, my comfort levels are at the perfect level for me. Nothing major is being compromised, and I’m definitely not going overboard with unnecessary comfort. So, am I materialistic? I’d say I’m in the middle, but probably not “in the middle” in the same way as most others who are also in the middle.

When my mother showed up at my house with a moving truck, I opened the door wearing a pair of black jeans with holes that exposed the backs of my thighs and my knees. There were bleach stains on the bottom, which had been worn ragged by my walking on the hems. That was the only pair of pants I owned. I didn’t see anything wrong with them. I didn’t leave the house aside from church. I had a skirt for that. We didn’t have money for anything else. Those pants, more or less, covered me. They served their purpose. I still have trouble remembering that my situation is nowhere near as dire as it was, and that I can buy things now. I am so used to living without, and making do with half-broken objects, that my instinct is to make everything last for as long as humanly possible before I cave and spend money. If I’m hungry, I look to flour and water. When I remember I can buy fruit, not for my son, but for me, I feel overwhelmed by my good fortune. I do this weekly. Every week it feels like a miracle. I got a mango the other day. I already wrote about this, but I’m still in awe. I ate it yesterday, the flavor was shockingly nuanced, the texture more stringy than I expected from such soft and pliant flesh. It wasn’t uniform at all. I don’t know if that’s what mangoes are supposed to be like. But it was incredible. I bought that. It’s difficult for me to discuss material objects without intense emotion. On one hand there is the awe and the gratitude, as I feel with the mango. On the other there is a persistent sense of anxiety; I do not buy things, I cannot buy things. This response is well-learned, conditioned. It’s how I survived. It’s how the lights stayed on. That’s not relevant anymore. But it’s hard for me to see objects I can buy as anything but a threat to my livelihood, as as threat to my physical safety. Before, if I bought a pair of jeans, the electricity might’ve gone out. If I ate too much, our water might’ve gotten shut off. I’ve been out of that situation for nine months now. My situation is comfortable. But after so long living in fear of spending money, it remains difficult to see objects that cost money as anything but a threat. Do I value material objects? Yes, they strike me as incredible and rare and valuable. But I also have an instinctive aversion to them, as spending money, any amount of money, has been a threat to my safety for so long.

No, definitely not. Not to be irritatingly sanctimonious here but “Stuff” has very little appeal for me and I don´t get any joy from shopping or consuming or having things at all. It leaves me feeling empty and sad. I moved country earlier this year and donated a lot of the stuff I´d accumulated during my time there and it was such a weight off my shoulders to size down like that. I was never a big consumer but I managed to accumulate stuff regardless. Since getting here in early January, I´ve bought almost nothing and have got good use out of the mountain of clothes I´ve accumulated over the years that I bought because I knew they wouldn´t go out of style quickly. I like to look well presented and I manage that without going shopping every month - I just look after the stuff I already have. The things I have bought has been because I´ve really needed them, like when shoes have fallen apart. I´ve tried to buy second-hand when I could (we have excellent second-hand clothes shops here in Amsterdam) and I´ve no issue with wearing others´ castaways if they´re in good condition. I got two lovely pair of Italian leather shoes for 50 Euro in one second-hand shop and people have complimented multiple times on them. My smart phone is a fairly basic model and I don´t have any fancy gadgets bar a pretty basic laptop. I don´t have a car (most people cycle here any way and a car would be useless here) and I don´t care about cars. I don´t care about brands or labels at all and don´t get the appeal. I genuinely want for nothing and prefer to spend my money on holidays or going out or just saving it for the future. I really can´t stand spending money replacing something that works perfectly well. My family and I are doing Secret Santa this year and, like every year, I´m struggling to think of something I want so my sister had to make a suggestion for me (some snazzy moisturiser or other). I saw that documentary recently, Minimalism and realised I´d been living that way pretty much my whole adult life and I could happily cut it back even more. Living an uncluttered life and making the most out of what you already have is a really satisfying, less stressful existence. I sound incredibly sanctimonious here, I know!

To an extent, yes. I like using the premium things in life but I don’t always could afford the price at an instant. I live comfortably right now, more like lower middle class. I probably could place myself in the upper middle class if I put in more hours at work but I value my time too much. Having said that, I live in two rooms apartment in a nice neighborhood with a housemate. We are both flying crews and earned slightly more than most of our peers around same age. We enjoy living the good life: good food, short vacation once every two/three months, splurging on cosmetics (our job requires us to do so), cute clothes once in a while and so on. We both have savings and drive our own car. But lets stop short over there. I am not as materialistic as one would assume. I can say, I am comfortably materialistic without having to go broke. Say, I am a trail runner and I would like to own the best hydration pack for my long rambling runs. Rather than buying cheap things, I would scout for high quality brands and make comparisons. I probably have to set aside money for a month or two but that is OK. It does not create a dent in my bank account. I justify buying these top of the range items as a long term investment. I ain’t got time to be fixing every month due to my lack of awareness to just spend it all at that one time and have the best quality. At times, I go overboard buying things that I probably could not afford. These mistakes are costly and would probably eat away at my sanity till the next paycheck so I am more cautious now. Having said that, I envy my mom. She still lives frugally that every time a hard time cimes knocking on her door, she is not fazed by it. I aspired to live like her, maybe soon, but not at this time. Life is too good to not enjoy it right now. The one thing that I probably took after her is the ability to make/create things from scratch rather than buying the ready made version of it. It has proven to save me lots of money in the long run. Nuralia Mazlan

Yes, but I am trying to be less so. There was a period where I spent money on things I thought I ought to own, but now I try to limit my spending to: Good quality and hardwearing outdoorsy stuffMerino wool clothing (I think I have settled on Rewoolution as my preferred brand for t-shirts)Shoes that fit (I am a US 13–14, UK 12–13 or EU 47–48, so this is a big deal)Bespoke suits and shirts, because they are what I wear most of the time and a proper fit makes a difference. I bought some new ones this year, but the previous batch of suits are now 6 years old and still in regular useBooks. Mostly books. Although increasingly these are ebooks.My mobile phone.I have a nice home cinema system but the newest components are 5 years old and the TV is over 10. I might renew the TV next year. There are also some bad decisions in there. We spent a lot moving our DVDs and BluRays onto a home cinema PC just as streaming made it irrelevant. We probably have far too much on DVD anyway. But as you get older, the realisation dawns that the things worth spending money on are the things you will remember. I want to spend more on travel and adventure. And I probably spend the majority of my post-tax income on my children.

Short answer: no. I haven’t bought new clothes since I was in 7th grade, and yes, now I’m in 12th. I work at Panda Express about 25 hours a week and I haven’t spent any of it on anything materialistic. I only spend it on food- is that any better? My parents force give me $20 a week and even though that is not a great sum of money for a week, I feel extremely guilty (I italicized force because I refuse it every time). My family moved from a very tiny house into a slightly larger house in a better neighborhood across from a beautiful park, and the main reason why I love the move is because of the location, not the house. I was content in my tiny house and I would continue to be content if I had stayed there my entire life. I value family time, and it made it virtually impossible to not have family time, as we were practically always running into each other, and I valued the vacations that we would go on every year, spending money on new experiences rather than on a home too big to house a 5 person family. My parents both have cars that are at least 8 years old and inexpensive, despite their ability to buy more expensive and modern cars without causing too much of a dent in their financial situation. My parents always emphasized the importance of health, happiness, and family. Fancy cars didn’t add to that, a big home didn’t add to that, and the newest flat screen 4G 934032GB LTE 4D TV sure as hell did not add to that. I grew up valuing concepts, not things. P.S. I do want to add that I am very fortunate and lucky to have grown up in a more-or-less financially stable household. I take absolutely nothing for granted and I understand that some people may gain ‘happy points’ from a fancy car or a fancy home, but I was raised differently- with different priorities and interests.

A2A. Not sure. I have a strong desire to be comfortable, but my definition of “comfortable,” I think, is pretty different than a lot of people. The only debt I have is student debt, and it’s well under 10K by this point. I pay off my credit cards every month. I have a few thousand in savings. This is what I consider comfortable; I don’t live beyond my means and my college payments are on a very comfortable monthly basis that I can easily pop off with a single writing job that will take me 4 hours. Considering I do at least 5 or 6 of these assignments a month and I have income from other sources as well, I’m actually very comfortable financially. That’s what I consider comfortable. Not having to worry about money. I do have nice things, though. I’m typing this on my 2017 MacBook I bought this last month (and it’s a glorious thing). I have Bose and Beats headphones, a big comfy bed, access to all the whiskey I could want, a wardrobe that is probably worth several thousand dollars at this point, and I’m getting ready to go spend an entire month in Europe. So I’ve got nice stuff. I’m well-educated. I’ve seen more of the world than most people probably ever will and I’m in my early 30s. I have multiple career options that I have entrenched resume lip-service for; since they’re all information-based they likely aren’t going to fizzle out anytime soon. I have more than enough to eat. I just don’t really have a desire for more stuff. I’m not terribly big on the idea of homeownership and never have been. I’ve never really wanted a car. I don’t want kids. I mean, I have wonderful electronics, a warm place to live, a comfortable place to sleep, I can dress up nice, and I have ridiculously flexible employment that I can change when I’m bored. I have paid-off credit cards and my debt is subsidized and under control. I can jet-set or pick up employment anywhere around the world if I want to do it. So it’s not that I’m not materialistic, I just have what I want in terms of material things. I’m a pretty happy person overall.

I’m very materialistic in some ways, less so than others. When I’ve moved out of the house, I’d love to have a little place of my own. Just a one-room flat, some secondhand furniture, a small television. I don’t want to own a car, and I have only a few pieces of cheap, sturdy jewelry that I wear all the time. However, I get very attached to things. I’ve had the same stuffed animals since I was a child; if there was ever a fire, they would be the first belongings I’d grab. I’ve been using the same computer for years, the same blankets, the same pillow. I’ve not had a wardrobe update since high school, and shoe shopping is a nightmare because I can’t bear the thought of replacing my beloved tennis shoes that have traveled so much with me. I don’t replace books when they start to fall apart; I grab tape and painstakingly secure the pages back together. I don’t place much value on these things because they’re expensive; I value them for the memories they carry.

Of course, yes. But it need not be in the pejorative context it seems to be, in your question. Products and services are tools. We humans are surrounded by tools including our voices, hands, types words, internet, etc.. Just tools. How we use the tools (or let the tools use us) is the question. I enjoy the high tech “materialism” in western society. But maybe as the pejorative implies, it can become a god (a slave to products/service with us serving it like our master and then it orchestrating us….the slave and master relationship as we remain deluded in a fog of pleasure and our wants turning into needs). So seeing how that process works, we can use the tools sensibly and if we develop no “god/addiction” (because we are cautious about using the tools), we are fine. So I think there need be no fear of a materialistic lifestyle IF the master-slave addiction process is well understood. But yes, we humans are a strange addiction-prone species. The concept of a transcendent good god was meant to lift us above these worldly human weaknesses/temptations (material gods). If we voluntarily decide to “serve” the abstraction of “ultimate goodness” (agape love), then these worldly temptations become obvious and are easy to avoid (the temptation, not the tool). If my words can be very harmful to myself and others, and I realize it, I can still use my voice but use it more wisely. Avoiding using my voice (the tool) because I know it can tempt me to say things I shouldn’t, is childish IMO. I don’t believe in isolation as a form of restraint. Karl Marx and cult leaders might like that approach, but I don’t. First, understand the temptation is in you, not in the tool and then change yourself so you can use the tool without falling to your temptation. If you cannot resist, then avoidance (putting yourself in your own little prison) is your only choice. But that’s like being a perpetual child needing mommy and daddy to protect you. Not much freedom in that. So maybe we have many immature “grown children” in society that get addicted to fast food, social networking, entertainment, high status and professionals telling them what to think, etc.. Maybe. But the answer is “awareness” to our addictive tendencies, not condemning the tools. Maybe it’s time to grow up and put our big boy pants on and use and even enjoy the tools without becoming childish addicts (like an immature kid in a candy store getting sick eating). But we all get to choose….which is why I like being an American.

Much more so than I would like, and much more so than it’s comfortable to admit. My theory is this: old money isn’t as materialistic as new money. And a recent memory of hunger is likely to trigger a greater desire for material comfort than would otherwise exist. Case in point: I’m more materialistic than your average American, but much less so than your average Ivorian. I have a friend from Venezuela in much the same situation. In the US, materialism is something to be ashamed of or apologetic about. In Ivory Coast, people go out of their way to flaunt their expensive belongings: Look at my expensive car. Look at my expensive clothes. Look at my huge house! That seems crass to me in a way I hope my own behavior won’t seem to my children. How is my materialism different, then? I drive a Lincoln. I bought it used—I’d never consider buying a brand new car—but I wanted a luxury car with heated/cooled leather seats and wooden paneling and all that stuff. Why? I don’t know. I just liked it.I fly first class whenever I can. Why? I like being pampered. And I can afford it now. So, why not?Given my choice of hotels, I’ll generally opt to stay at a Hyatt. It’s not super duper expensive, but there are definitely cheaper options. But staying at a Hyatt makes me happy. And now that I’m used to this, staying somewhere less nice feels like I’m cheating myself out of something I deserve. If I live somewhere cold, as I currently do, I insist on having an attached garage. It’s non negotiable.I like matching my hats with the rest of my outfits. So, in winter, I have hats in several colors: black, brown, burgundy, navy, green, etc. Why? Because it makes me happy. When I buy my adult house, it’s going to be bigger than what I strictly need. Why? I want an office, and an exercise room, and a bedroom. I’d occupy 3 rooms by myself.I like nice clothes. I love soft fabrics that caress my skin. If I buy a sweater, it’s going to be merino wool, or some silk blend, or occasionally cashmere. Why? Those are just the fabrics I happen to like. Interestingly, I can’t stand alpaca or lambswool: I itch like a sonofabitch.I chose a profession that pays more, as opposed to one that pays less but that I might have had more affinity for.I think that about covers it.

I have a thing for healthy and tasty food. I have a weak tummy, so I always choose healthy food over fast food. There are not many fast foods to my taste, so I don’t cry over its lack. I don't have to struggle with the constant ‘drug’ that I see in so many people over wanting to eat fast food and complaining the very next day that it worsened their tummy. At the very best, I like cakes and pastries. Those little fluffy objects are the only cellulite in my body. I am small. Basically, I hate to be unhealthy. I cross oceans to keep my health in check. Then I always wear washed, neat and clean clothes. Since I am hyperhydrotic, I particularly invest in good shoes and socks. Plus, I love water. Bathing means using more than excess water a child of my stature would need for bathing. I can go on without bathing, but when I bath, I bath for real. I like to spend on a healthy and hygienic lifestyle. I like to sleep comfortably. Resting my mind and body is just as important to me as surviving. Reading newspapers refreshes the mind. Having a good internet connection and devices to access it is also what I pay a great attention to. I don’t care about the cost of things, if it’s usable, I am good to go. I am writing this answer on a cheap Redmi phone which doesn't sell anymore now and wearing a much cheaper watch. I don't need to launch a rocket, what good is a costly phone going to do to me? A watch is simply going to tell me time, no matter its cost. So far the only thing that's been costly in my life is my undergrad college – the one that I am attending now. The fees here is sky high. Lately, I came across Timberland. It's boots are like no other boots I have seen. Note that I am not a fan of boots and extravagant shoes but Timberland’s 6′inch premium boots caught my attention and I haven’t been able to get it off my mind since then. It's too costly to be worn. It’s costly and I like it. I wish to wear them someday. To sum it all, I need a decent way of living to carry on, where my body gets optimum rest and sleep and regains the power to function well the next day. I like to spend on health and body, because that’s what the real struggle in this world is for. If that’s what you would call materialistic, then, perhaps I am one. If not, then I am not.

I’m among the least materialistic people I know, if by materialism we mean measuring success and accomplishment based on the accumulation of stuff, and equating said stuff with happiness or fulfillment. I could be about as happy living in a bale of hay with a few quilts, or in a van, as in a luxury apartment. That’s only a very slight exaggeration. And yes, while I’m more fortunate than many and do count my blessings in that respect, I have lived under some pretty itinerant and uncertain conditions in my time; this is the voice of experience I’m using, not pure conjecture. It’s not in my nature to derive any kind of sentimental value from inanimate objects — I simply don’t “get” keepsakes. If Mom gives me something and says, “Here, take care of this, I want you to have it,” then I’ll be touched by that and will certainly safeguard it. Doesn’t mean it will be anywhere near me on the day-to-day. The memories in my head are the keepsakes I live among, for better or for worse. In short: the fewer physical objects (and bills) I have to keep up with, the happier I am. I think this is because inner life has always been far more vivid to me than the environment, even to a fault. I’m not impervious to consumerism, but I’m a damn difficult case as far as that goes, and proud of it. I do have a streak of materialism, I suppose, when it comes to certain gadgets and to the tools of my trade (as a musician). I very much believe in investing in the best equipment for the job, whatever it takes.

Not very much at all. I try to apply the following principle - when I see something I think I would like I ask myself to distinguish the difference between “need” and “want”. If I don’t “need” it, I usually don’t get it. I am married but we only have one car. My husband has a work vehicle, but he uses it to get to and from work and of course while on the job. We make it work. We are not fad followers. Everyone seems to have a mega home entertainment centre. We just have a t.v. and DVD player. My life is not going to be greatly enhanced by having all of the stuff that will make it sound like we are in a movie theatre. Is it really worth it to spend all of that money (not to mention the hassle of hooking it all up)? I don’t think so. I call that perspective. There was a time when I spent a fair amount of money on clothing but I don’t anymore. To give you some idea of my sartorial state of affairs-I am going to have surgery tomorrow and last week I had to go and buy a nightgown to wear for the week I will be there because my only other summer nightgown is over 10 years old, faded and tatty. I stick to cargo pants and t-shirts for everyday wear and sandals or tennis shoes. The pots and pans in my kitchen are 22 years old. They are still in good shape and do the job so I will keep using them. We seldom go out to eat. Instead, we make meals that last several days. Eating out where we live is expensive and it just feels wrong to spend that much. I do have some things that I do spend a fair amount of money on but I feel it is justified: My garden. I live on 10 acres and have lots of garden space and trees. I also love to put plants in pots both inside and outside. Plants are cheap, but pots can cost a bit. But I get immense joy planting them and looking after them. As for my gardens, I am unable to maintain them due to my health so I have to pay someone. They come once a month to weed, prune, etc. and sometimes plant new things or replace things that have died. At $30 per person per hour plus materials, this can be expensive. But it is worth it because I enjoy the beauty plus it enhances the value of my property. This makes good sense in the long term. Travel. I love to travel whether it is within the country where I live or overseas. I fly at the pointy end of the plane simply because my health means I need to be able to lie down when travelling for 14 hours. To save money, we will rent a small cabin/cottage so that we can make our own meals rather than stay in hotels, which cost more and don’t have cooking facilities. We live within our means, aren’t worried about keeping up with the Joneses and while we live in the now we are always thinking about and preparing for the future. I would like to have a comfortable old age so I try to be sensible now.

For Christmas I am getting the promise of a few hundred dollars towards a laptop. “Promise,” because no one has a few hundred dollars. And a new laptop only because my current one is borderline non-functioning. I work from home. Having a reliable computer is not really an option. In essence, I am getting nothing for Christmas and I am content with that. I am an avid pursuer of things. I like things. I have spent a lot of time acquiring them only to let them breathe on my shelves like these stagnant little air-suckers. I move. A lot. I’ve moved multiple times a year for the past two years. Every time I move, I get rid of shit because it’s heavy. I don’t want to carry it. If I’m not willing to haul it down the stairs, then it ain’t worth keeping. I’ve acquired fewer and fewer things because each thing I acquire is another thing that must be moved. This is one time where my chronic laziness is a strength. It makes me get rid of shit. I am defensive of my things. I like my things. Slowly but surely, though, I’m letting them go. We lost our house last year. This is not a secret on Quora, not to me, anyway. Great-great grandpa built it, it’d been in the family for a hundred years, yadda yadda yadda. It’s gone now. It’s not ours. It never will be. Saying that makes my breath catch in my throat and I really want to cry now but it’s just a thing. That thing didn’t tell me that good ol’ Grandpa Gus had a fling with the housekeeper after his wife passed. That thing didn’t tell me about the time Grandpa Pete’s pants fell down in the front yard and he finished watering the lawn before pulling them back up (the man had his priorities straight). That thing held nothing. It was nothing. It was the heart of my family but it was not my family. We keep my family lefse and prayers and “mange tusen takk” and our blonde hair but even without all of that we keep our family in us. In the people. Not the things. We keep ourselves in people, too—in the stories they tell, about us, about our world. We are not our things. As much as I would cry at the loss of everything I own, in the end, I am not these things and they are not me. When you die, someone throws your newspaper scraps away, the ones you so meticulously snipped from your favorite stories. Someone donates your favorite books to kids who will rip at their pages and adults who will tatter their covers. Someone boxes up your wedding band and maybe it goes to a family member or maybe someone melts it down, boils it all away. We acquire shit and then we die, and then it’s someone else’s problem. As much as I’d like to look at this answer and say “No, I am not materialistic,” I am because I still want things. Even knowing they aren’t me. Even knowing they will not follow me when I die. I like things. I am not too materialistic, no. But there’s no denying that I am.

The idea of material goods as unfulfilling and hollow has always struck me as incomplete. We’re supposed to value experiences over possessions, but I see them as necessarily intertwined: if you want to go on a camping trip with your family, you need access to camping equipment. Perhaps what folks have in mind is that material possessions which don’t translate into experiences are not worthwhile. Well, yes, but that just sounds like a bad purchase. If you’re effective at ascertaining what you will and will not have constructive uses for, this advice becomes less valuable. I commute across state lines, and I have invested quite a bit of time into figuring out what accessories make this commute work. I have little doubt that this investment has paid off. Some of the things I take every day: A folding bike, for the parts between train ridesNoise-canceling headphones, to reduce stress and distraction from ambient train noiseA laptop, for doing work on the trainAn insulated water bottle, so I can drink cold water throughout the dayWindproof gloves, earmuffs, and a mask, so I can bike comfortably when it’s cold outsideA smartphone, which I use to buy train ticketsIn each case, the most relevant question to me is whether the benefit from carrying the item will outweigh the cost. Asking whether I’m being materialistic feels like a slightly less useful version of the same question. Ultimately, I do tend to think of myself as pretty materialistic. I have positive feelings about taking advantage of consumer surplus, and I keep an eye out for more opportunities to do so. I’m certainly not a minimalist. But I also have no interest in conspicuous consumption or in buying more stuff than I can use. So I guess it depends on the definition of materialistic.

There are only a few things I need to survive to be honest. A small room with a laptop, WiFi, a gaming console, and a wide screen television/monitor with an output to a 3.1 or 5.1 surround system.  I had this sorted out the moment I got my first job and my demands have never increased further than that. I have just upgraded the television to a larger display size to watch soccer, cricket and formula 1. Of course, I always had my book collection.  Of course, I gave them all way since it is much easier to have everything on a kindle. I know, paperbacks are better, the aroma of a new book is awesome but I had over 250 novels and it was impossible to carry it around as I travel a lot. And the final nail in the coffin were bikes.  I have two of them, and probably would buy one more sometime later. That is all I ever wanted. A small room to rest, books to read and a few bikes to ride. I am not much particular about what I wear, what I eat, where I live as long as I have these things and a mug of beer. I am not particular about brands, social status and all that unnecessary evil the society feeds us.  So, I think I maybe a semi-modern-materialistic person at the most. I am more of a ‘people-istic’ guy.

upvoters.user_id: ASHISH M BHAT Dept of ISE

response.answer_text: My hobbies are expensive, so I’m materialistic by extension. I don’t want things but I want to make money. I don’t care about fancy clothing and will eat whatever keeps my stomach full. I don’t want expensive watches, latest phones or gadgets. I want to make money because: I enjoy traveling and I enjoy cars. Both of these cost a shit ton of money. In order to enjoy my hobbies I have to make a lot of money. Just look at this beautiful piece of machinery, it’s worth it. Growing up, my family wasn't very well off and we had a lot of money problems. I can trace back most of our struggles as a family to the lack of money. That is another reason why I want to have money, whether I need it or not. The freedom that comes with money is important to me.I think that’s about it.

Yes. While I understand the idea of being happy with what you have, I appreciate my upgraded lifestyle. I left my job a few months ago to go back to school, and really appreciate my savings which allow me to continue in my lifestyle. I really like being able to take a cab without thinking about its cost, being able to fly across the country instead of taking a train to go home or meet my friends. I like that I am able to go to a fine dining place infrequently without worrying about my budget. I appreciate the Mac which I use throughout the day. Having said that, I don’t fancy fine clothes, a great mobile phone or a high-end car. My fascination is usually either stuff that I use a lot (such as my laptop or my bicycle) or concern for a minimum level of comfort (such as a decent hotel room or an airline of my choice instead of the cheapest available). In conclusion, I think I am fairly materialistic about certain things, while being indifferent about most others.

I’m not at all materialistic except when it comes to all things Apple tech. There, I’m as materialistic as they come — just for the fun of it. I have a MacBook Air,an iPad Air,an iPad Pro with its attendant Apple Pencil and Apple’s Smart Keyboard cover,an iPhone SE,an Apple Watch, andApples’ new AirPods.If I don’t get one for Christmas, I’m pretty sure I’m going to buy myself a MacBook Pro. I’d already have an iPhone X but I’m waiting for the kinks to be worked out first. That too I’ll likely get after Christmas. I’d already have a 27″ iMac with Retina Screen but that I’ve no place to put one. I did buy my sister a 21″ iMac only because her desk hasn’t room for the 27″. I also bought her an iPad Air and would have bought her an iPhone but she won’t have a mobile phone. In all these things, of course, I have to have the fastest processor and the greatest amount of RAM and SSD storage, not because I actually need them but just because I have to. Other than this one minor exception, I’m not at all materialistic.

Almost not at all. I have never valued “stuff.” I want experiences. I want my own and other people's in the form of books, essays, articles, stories, travel, communion, friendships, affairs. I want my privacy most of the time. My nest needs to be comfortable, clean, and easy to maintain. No long hours of maintenance and cleaning for me, please. I don't want fashion labels. I do want clothes that fit, feel comfortable, and speak plainly to everyone that I am a person of simple, but respectable taste. I grew up poor for an American.[1] We were poor, but we were privileged. My siblings and I knew beyond doubt that while we didn't have much, that we could become whatever we wished. My brother became very wealthy and a serious materialist. My sister became a serious teacher devoted to a large family and to supporting the accomplishments of her extraordinarily gifted children. Me? I crave experience over stuff. I want to know everything there is to know, feel everything there is to feel, love everyone available to love. All before my ephemeral spark of consciousness fades back into the unknowing fire of univeral being. No, I am not materialistic. Much. Footnotes[1] James Finn's answer to What is your experience growing up poor in the USA?

Am I materialistic? Hmmnn… I’m not sure. I own lots of things but I tend to own things that let me do stuff. I don’t buy stuff because it’s the latest or the most fashionable but I do try to buy stuff that I judge to be the best for what I want. I hate shopping. But when I have to buy something I’m too poor to be cheap. I’d rather spend £200 for a pair of hand made workboots that will last me years, than £20 on a pair that will do just as well for a short time but I’ll have to go through the trauma of shopping for in another six months. If my expensive boots last me five years I’ve broken even. Every month they last after that I’m in profit. The pair I’m wearing just now are six years old so I’m £40 ahead. I have a large expensive custom built house. I couldn’t do without the space, and yes I know seven bedrooms is too big for one man but d’you know what? I built it myself on land I owned and it probably cost me less than someone else might spend on a two bedroom condo. When the kids and the family are round the space is certainly useful. Would I ever spend the same on a two bed condo? No. Don’t care where it is - it’s not worth it to me. Would I like another bigger house? Nah, next one I build will be smaller. I never buy the latest gadget or gizmo. Not if I can possibly avoid it. My laptop is a six year old Dell, my phone a four year old hand me down Samsung from my eldest daughter. I couldn’t care less if they’re fashionable or not. They work, in fact they work very well and that’s all I want. I buy cars that are almost completely depreciated. I’m not going to buy new and lose a couple of thousand the minute I drive it off the lot. I’ve got other things to spend that money on. No I buy cars that are around ten years old, old diesels that will give me another hundred thousand miles or so at negligible cost. I’m happy to put in a bit of work to get it going and keep it going well, but the minute it needs work that costs more than 50% of it’s replacement value - out it goes. I usually get three to five years or so out of a £2500 car. A happy formula I’ve worked to for years. If I had bought it new, I’d have lost more than my total costs for that time on the day I drove it home. What’s the point of that? Would I like a brand new Porsche? Nah - but you might tempt me with an old air cooled 993. As a carpenter though I do have a weakness for buying tools. And I spend far too much on them! For work I buy tools that will do the best job for the most cost effective price - it’s a fine balancing act, often the most expensive tool isn’t necessarily the best. And sometimes the rise in cost for a minimal rise in effectiveness or efficiency isn’t worth the difference in price so I’ll research carefully before buying - but I won’t hesitate to pay what I need to get the right tool for the job. I was talking to someone the other day about my toaster. It’s a six slot Dualit, he said something along the lines of how he didn’t expect me to have something so fashionable. I told him I’d had it for over 20 years, it was second hand and already around 20 years old when I bought it. For £5. Keep something quality long enough and it becomes fashionable again. So am I materialistic? I don’t know. I hate buying stuff, but I buy a lot of stuff - but most of the stuff that I do buy works for a living or lasts a long time.

10 years ago I had a PS2. I had several games for this PS2 all secondhand. I had a big old TV my grandfather got me before he passed. I had a few toys too most notably a bag filled to the brim with toy soldiers, tanks, jenga blocks and planes. Poundland toys made of cheap plastic. I had a few books mainly from before dad died. Horrible Histories mostly. My clothes were hand-me-downs from my mothers work colleagues (she worked 2 hours a day as a dinnerlady then four hours late afternoon as a librarian). I wore the same school uniform for four years. My school actually gave me shoes on more than one occasion because the ones I had became so worn they had mouths wjere my toes would peep out. Fast forward ten years… I have a PS2 and PS3 with several secondhand games. The big TV is still here but I use a very small secondhand TV that isn't huge. I still have those toy soldiers somewhere but it's been a long time since I played with them. They seem to be something I would pass onto a son of mine later in life. I don't own nor read many books. I have the entire works of HP Lovecraft on my phone however. My clothes are not hand me downs anymore (well, except a striped hoodie I wear to work). I buy my clothes cheap and my cashmere winter coat I got for under a tenner from a charity shop. Naturally I don't wear a school uniform anymore and I wear two kinds of shoes ; work boots and plain formal cheap shoes. I own a couple band shirts and the odd horror ornament but if I had to grab everything I owned it would not take me a long time.

I have a complicated relationship with things. On one hand, I really, really like pretty things. I scour thrift stores, refinish furniture, re-hem dresses. I have collections and I have so much artwork, I rotate it, like a museum. There have been several periods of my life where my eye for pretty things and my aesthetic choices have paid my bills. On the other hand, I am very frugal. I hate clutter and bother. I have no urge or reason to impress anyone. I don’t buy what I don’t need or can’t sell in a pinch. I wear a uniform of jeans, boots and black t-shirts most days. I save sartorial splendor for special occasions. I eat nice food, mostly because I cook it myself. I’ve paid off my debt (except for student loans, those are never going away) I drive a serviceable car. I live in a clean, modest duplex. I spend too much time cleaning and arranging my space. I don’t want anything, but I am restless and visually driven. I long for a minimalist life, but I have a knack for acquiring shiny things. I will always struggle between trying to create my own little world and trying to uncomplicated my little world.

Quite a bit, to be honest. I very much identify with the following quote: “Money may not buy happiness, but I'd rather cry in a Jaguar than on a bus.” ― Françoise Sagan Let’s be honest, being able to afford nice things is, well, nice. It’s pleasant. Inviting your fiance to an upscale restaurant and spending a great evening is a big benefit, so I want to be able to afford it. Is that necessary? No. I personally would never date a person who insists on upscale restaurants and shuns having a cheap picnic on a deserted beach at sundown. But it’s better to be able to have both options instead of being stuck with one. Will it make your happy? Hopefully you are happy with your fiance no matter where you take her, so the obvious answer is no. But here comes the catch - spending time with your favorite person is something you need to be able to afford. You can’t do that if you are working 2–3 jobs to make ends meet; and that brings me to the second, even better quote: “Time is money.” - Benjamin Franklin Usually people say it to express that time is valuable. But it also means that money can buy time. Working in a field where a regular work week pays several times more than some 60+ hour patchwork of part-time jobs means more time is available to you. More time to spend with people you love.More time to do things you enjoy.More time to relax and cherish life.You all know the quote “the best things in life are free”. Well, that’s not completely true. If you don’t have the time and the money to visit your family, spend time with your partner, raise your children, have a decent place to live, etc. - then chances are you won’t get to enjoy the best things at all. Also, it’s less likely you even get to know these “best things” in the first place. I moved to Munich for attending university. Munich is the most expensive German city. If I wouldn’t have been able to afford that, I would not have met my girlfriend, would not know half of my best friends, would not have the job I’m having (and enjoying), etc. To conclude, I cherish the benefits of materialism, but I am not blinded by it.
