I agree that things alone won’t make me happy. And I honestly admire people who are at least as happy as I am who give a sh*t about stuff and live a frugal life. But I personally value the comfort of stuff. Oh, and before I leave: “The best things in life are free. The second best things are very, very expensive.” ― Coco Chanel

I am hardly interested in new clothes, jewellery, bikes or cars, gadgets and other things which people who are conventionally “materialistic” have yearnings for. However being a huge book lover, I realize I was getting too attached to my book, that is building a library in my room, never wanting to lend or donate the books. This made me feel miserable because while I was really interested in having my own library, the books were untouched since years(after I had read them) and had no one else to read them. This was unfair according to me, since it made no sense for books to sit idle rather than being read. So, this Christmas, I packed 25–30 of my favourite books from my shelves, and sent out to people whom I have liked talking to online but could never get a chance to meet. The feeling I got from being the secret book Santa was phenomenal, but more amazing was the whole process of letting go. I felt free knowing I was not crumbling with sadness while having to give those books away. The separation was just fine and I felt amazing to have finally understood that I cared about reading more than physically possessing books(which is a positive sign I think). Also,I can say now, I am not a very materialistic person.

Not very. I’ve long since reached material equilibrium in my life. With the exception of food, I only buy new things for myself if I need to replace an old thing. It makes Christmas shopping for me very difficult, according to my family. I’d rather have experiences than material things. We have too much crap in this house as it is, and very little of it is mine. I sometimes see things I would like when I’m out and about, but my mind always thinks: “You’d use this for an hour, get bored of it, and then it would just be another thing taking up space in your house until you donate it to charity.” So I don’t buy it. Instead I go to the nearest coffee place, buy a coffee, have an hour of enjoyment drinking it, throw away the cup, and have zero added clutter in my house. Lately I’ve been thinking that, if I were maybe 5 years younger and never met my wife, I would have totally been on the “little house” bandwagon. As it was, by the time that became a popular thing, I already had a big house and a family.

I was travelling in Tanzania and Kenya with a group of friends. Before the trip we decided to put all our money together, share the meals and pay for everything with the common cash. It was one of the best experiences ever. It just felt so natural and smooth not having to think about money; not having to stress about owning things. However, I’m not naive. Even if I support sharing certain things with your neighbours and not counting whose turn it is to pay when you eat out with your friends, different people naturally have a very different relationship with money — and that may cause problems if you are supposed to share too many things. I also recognize that it really matters to me if my surroundings are beautiful. And sometimes you have to pay for that beauty. So I honestly think I’m not materialistic as in living in luxury; I don’t need a fancy smartphone, and living in a huge elegant house would feel just… alienating. But I might be materialistic, when it comes to being able to surround myself with vintage lamps from the 60’s or bake my bread in colourful enamel bowls.  (Photo source: Kulho, Finel) For me that means that my home really feels like home. Actually I also think that loving material things is not bad. I prefer to love them enough to take care of them and not having to buy so many new things.

Yes and no. In my closet, I have maybe ten plain articles of clothing that I've owned for years and years. I have over 500 pieces of jewelry. I donate my stuff monthly to thrift stores, anything and everything I can find. I have three desks in my art studio. For that matter, I have an art studio. I'm a saver. I would rather put my money in a piggy bank than a cash register. I still have my baby blankets. For cuddle purposes. Honestly, I'm either a minimalist or a hoarder. The truth is, I have a lot of stuff. I enjoy my stuff. I like my life where I never want for anything. And I dream of a future where I have nothing but the clothes on my back, a plan, and the road in front of me. I have more than I need and I hate that. But I also have exactly what I want right now. And I think that's okay. I will someday have less than most people in the United States and I love that. I embrace that. I look forward to it. And that's okay, too.

We are all materialistic because of our attachments to things, feelings, ambitions, people. I don't derive any pleasure from the things we possess. In fact, come to think of it, there are very few ' things' which I have bought for myself. We live in a decent house and have a decent car. Kids get a good education. All within limits. No luxuries. That's it. In fact, I haven't bought much with whatever money I have made till now.  This doesn't excite me !  Neither does this !  Nor does this. Well, not because it's not within reachable heights, but that's just not what will make me happy! In that sense I am not materialistic. This makes me happy.  And this.  And this.  Yes, in that sense I am materialistic. I don't mind it though !

We’d not long moved into our university house and my housemates and I had spent a few days making it into a home. Obviously, we all decorated our own rooms. I walked into my housemates’ rooms to see photographs, posters, and shelving full of things. When they came to my room, well, to say they were underwhelmed is somewhat something of an understatement. “I appreciate your… minimalism,” they jibed. “Seriously, Fred, where the hell is everything?” “I don’t like stuff,” was my blunt reply. And I say it all the time: I don’t like stuff. I think we have too much of it. I will be going to my parents’ for Christmas. They have a lot of things. You can’t get through the front door before you notice some weird new trinket they’ve bought. My dad is especially bad; I think he spends money just for the sake of spending money (not to mention, money he doesn’t really have). So I think this is in part my rejection of that. I can’t stand unnecessary mess. I don’t see the point of keeping things just for the sake of keeping them. I’d go as far as to say I find it unhealthy. Obviously I have my own ornaments and bits and pieces that I keep because they have meaning. If it doesn’t have a purpose or meaning behind it, it gets thrown. That is what I value above all: meaning and purpose.

Yes, I am. I like things. Strangely, it seems, the things I like cost money. I want to decorate my house with commissioned art pieces and historical items because it pleases me to see them. I want to fill my cabinet with fine whiskeys and premium lagers because it pleases me to drink them. I want to cover my shelf with the latest video games because it pleases me to play them. I don't flash money, and have no desire to. I don't own a single designer clothing item. I don't spend extra for names. I still don't fully understand why gold is so valuable. But when it comes to stuff I care about, stuff that makes my life easier, more fun, or more fulfilling, I like to have the money to pay for it.

Not at all. I make an ok living. But I still live cheaply.  I have the smallest house in the neighborhood. If I made a million dollars a year, I don't know that I'd move right away. I'd probably just upgrade all of my electronics and decorate a little. Showing off wealth is a silly thing to me, never understood it. So you certainly wouldn't see me flashing a $10,000 watch. Ain't nobody got time for dat.

Last night I went to a neighbor’s Christmas Eve party. She has a lovely home - so well-decorated and beautifully presented for the holidays. They renovated one of the bedrooms into a sitting room/ library for their daughter as a 16-year birthday surprise. It’s beautiful. They have a small hedgehog which has its own carrying pouch and the heating pad. Looking around I was thinking how we should probably renovate/ upgrade our own home. And maybe even get a heating pad for myself, as I would enjoy it as much as their hedgehog. But, my family is always on the go and out and about so investing a lot of money and time into the house seems to be a waste. Right now we are getting ready to go to a ski area for a week. And I’m OK with the way things are, though I may become a bit more materialistic later down the road as I get older.

Enough to want to achieve financial security, & a certain degree of comfort - I'm not interested in luxury goods & designer brands, nor will I deliberately eschew any of the finer things - I'm not interested in gold taps, a diamond encrusted smartphone, nor would I insist on having liveried footmen attending to all my needs - luxury gets boring - there is a condition known as "affluenza" - the boredom & indifference of the leisurely rich - the ennui - something that I hope will never happen to me.As Abraham Lincoln said: "You can't help the poor by being one of them."There is no virtue in poverty, & once our material needs are met - we can flourish - the renaissance happened because of wealth & peace, nor is wealth an obstacle to spirituality - there are many wealthy people that help others a great deal, philanthropists, heads of charities and so on.

Personally, I don't care one bit about material things. It's to the point where my boyfriend used to buy me surprise gifts but my reaction was so flat that he stopped. HE likes nice things. I don't care. But when I compared our childhoods, I kinda understand it. When he grew up, his family was poor and they knew it. He didn't have anything nice and used friends' toys and games. So now that he is an adult, if he sees something he likes he buys it without hesitation. My childhood was different. We were poor but didn't know it. My mom cared more about name brand shoes and clothes than about rent. So we moved a lot, eventually losing most of the nice things we had. As we grew older and my dad left, she was still doing the same thing except only for herself, even leaving is home alone with no food or money while she went out to eat with her man friend. She never brought anything back for us. So there is a reason behind everything a person does, consciously or not. Whenever he goes shopping, I immediately start to worry about how we will pay the rent. Didn't even realize that until I just wrote it out. Explains a lot. I could not care less about materialistic things but he is constantly collecting random nice things, just because.

I used to be a materialistic person but not anymore. My childhood was very simple just like every other middle-class kid But things changed when I was in my teenage. I started earning at the age of 17. I was a science student but more interested in making money. I borrowed some money from my father and invested in the stock market. Repaid him from the profits and spend the rest on gadgets. I bought everything in the later years ranging from gaming PC to Sports bike, shoes and clothes and whatnot. I had a dedicated showcase in my room made of glass where I kept all my gadgets and their boxes. There was a time when I was crazy about motorcycles and gadgets. Talking about the last few years, I bought 2 Royal Enfield classic 350, bought gadgets for about 1 lakh, spend around a lakh on liquor and cigarettes, laptop, mobile etc But from last year, I haven’t bought a single new gadget. I used to have more 15 pairs of shoes, numerous jeans, and shirts which I never wore.One day I sat down and picked up the things I never used. I gave them away to my friends and people who really needed such things or were about to buy such things.Cut down to present scenario: Now I can tell you what exactly I own. There was a time when I was so materialistic that I never look beyond gadgets but now I barely use them. I have a phone which is only used for taking calls and booking tickets (I travel a lot).You won’t find a single social networking app, shopping app on my phone. Do I regret changing my lifestyle? Not a bit. I feel more organized because I have left with the things that I literally use and not just show-off.I invested that time in reading books and thinking about future business ventures. Earlier I was more living a fake life and thus worried about maintaining an Image. Now I am living a life which I want and without worrying about the image. How did this happen?I would give the credit to my girlfriend and my friend cum mentor Rohit Agarwal. They both taught me the real value of life and how life is not about “Possessions”.Life is not about possessions, cars or gadgets, it is about how much you enjoy it through your experience. Before anyone gets any wrong Idea, I am not against money or basic necessities. I feel money matters and you should use the money to fulfill your basic necessities, but at the same time don’t fall into the materialistic pit.

Nope. Since childhood, my parents have taught me to be a spiritually inclined person. Material wealth doesn't fascinate me. I believe, we are all part of a grand universal scheme. Our collective aim must be to synergize with higher consciousness through medium such as meditation. In fact, I have bought Bose Sound Touch 20 Series III Wireless Music System just for sake of playing meditation music in background, while meditating on my velvet mat. I'm also looking for a sea facing bungalow, so that I can meditate and connect with nature more intimately That way, I'm very spiritual.

No, I am realistic,as I give importance to luxuries and material necessities. I was not knowing in my very young age that life will put me in situation that I would be extremely craving for all the luxuries that one should have to live good life. Being from good earning family, I had everything. My own room , vehicle,big house. At that time I don't had importance of all that things. I never thought how one could live without them. I thought people who do not have all this thing can live with necessary things. And their Life goes easy. I just want to thanks to my destiny. Teach me lesson. And let me know the reality. I am fed up of this simple life struggling for everything. For cooking,washing .dusting. I need equipments. To work smoothly. I need home with facilities. To live with leisure. Less or more everyone is materialistic.If they want to live good life it plays important role. And nothing is wrong in it. Yes I want to earn more money to have more materialistic luxuries.

I live a very simple life, almost a monks life by comparison, to a person I know I on here. I will explain. My bills are paid on time every month, and I have money left over, and I am happy, my savings account is building up nicely. I was gifted 2 new pairs of jeans, and I’ll cherish them well, but mostly I’ve worn the same clothes for years, because the were made to last. and when a family member is struggling, I can give them money, and that gives me more pleasure than all the shite, and other things you can buy, material wealth means so little.. I find it laughable that people measure wealth in such a way.. And for those who think I’m religious, stick your religion up your arse, I don’t need a god of any sort telling me what to do is right or wrong..

Enough that I come off snobbishly. I like quality. I like design. I like luxury. I’m not going to pretend I don’t love my mulberry bag, my Burberry coat, or my PH lamp. I do. But they are not the only things I care about. But I was ridiculously thrilled to get a friend who has the money and class to go with me to Michelin restaurants and on shopping sprees to Mont Blanc. Life is just more fun if you’re surrounded by nice things. How materialistic are you?

upvoters.user_id: Iván J. Andrade (イヴァンあんどらで)

response.answer_text: This really fluctuates with how much money I have at disposal. Until about a year ago I was a student in a foreign country whose only occasional income was from giving private lessons in German (not a very lucrative business, I’m afraid to say). During this time I don’t think I was materialistic at all. I was happy enough I had a first-hand contract for a two-room apartment (a rarity in Stockholm)! Rent, food, public transport and the occasional travels to my family were all my expenses and pretty much all I needed. However, now I work as a PhD candidate at the university I used to study. In Sweden, they actually pay you a salary for that, can you believe it? Since then, I’ve noticed that I’ve gradually become more materialistic. Commercials have a much bigger impact on me simply because these days I pause and think to myself: “Huh. I could actually buy this!” When I see something nice that is within my budget I often go ahead and buy it. Simply because I can. I’m wondering what you can extrapolate from this data: should I ever become rich will I be needing to rent a truck for every trip to the mall?

I disagree with Asim Qureshi who I respect a ton but I think he’s kind of full of crap. Deep down we all have a bit of narcissism and materialistic tendencies. I in no way think materialism is the main driver for everybody. But it drives everybody in some way. To be materialistic is in some way to be human. Like I told a good friend of mine the other day, I think we all have an area that makes us super shallow. Listen, I can sit here and say that I don’t compare myself to other entrepreneurs and measure my success against theirs but that would be a lie. Men especially like to keep score. And keeping score is a form of being materialistic. If liking to keep score is materialistic then I’m the most materialistic. Some of us show our materialism in fashion. Not me of course because I’m one bad outfit away from looking like a homeless guy. Either way we’re all guilty of our idolatry. Every person has their version of materialism. It’s the human condition. Sure some of us go to mountain retreats and meditate for 3 days and get rid of 99% of our material belongings, thank you James Altucher. But we all keep score in some way. Deep down every person knows what is materially important to them. And we’re all kind of ashamed to admit it.

I thought i was very materialistic, but then i noticed i was far less materialistic than some people. So i’d say am pretty much average. I like things and i need things, but those things that i need i already own except an house. I really would like to own my own house! Just because its a step closer to freedom and privacy. If you have no possessions its harder to have a free lifestyle unless you have no complex about being “different” and live in the woods or something. In short, Yes, but not more than anyone else.

It depends. I can be materialistic in some ways and sentimental. For example a relative gave me a teddy bear as a kid, I still have it years later even though I’m nearly 22. I can’t bear to replace my trainers and I’d love to live in a flat that is kinda of close to my childhood house. When my books fall apart, I attempt to use glue or tape to put them back together- I don’t throw them away. Why should I? I value those objects due to the memories gained from them. Not because they’re expensive. If my house caught fire, my books would be one of the first things that would be grabbed up as I fled. Along with my phone and teddy bears of course. Shoe shopping is hell. Everyone is materialistic in some way I suppose. I’m kinda of a hoarder.

Are you materialistic? I think that most of us living in the western world are materialistic, but by western standards, I think that I am relatively unmaterialistic. Our house was built for my parents over 60 years ago and needs some improvements, particularly the kitchen.My car, a Ford Focus, is 12 years old and has done 173,000 miles. I bought it when it was one year old.My phone is about 2 years old. It is a Samsung A3, fairly basic by smart phone standards. I have a £15 per month contract.I have a second hand laptop PC that was given to me.I rarely buy shoes, only to replace a worn out pair. I rarely buy clothes too, Fortunately, we have a casual dress code at work.

I am generally, but it depends. I will choose street food over McD, I will choose sitting under sky over having a long drive in a BMW. I will choose walking over a bike ride, I will appreciate your effort if you ever cook for me than to have a dinner in a high class restaurant. (we can always order a pizza if food is a disaster) I will choose any working phone over an iPhone. But yes, money never hurts, does it? I will be happy even if I don't have these, I am happy the way I am. I will be happy if I have expensive stuff. If being materialistic makes you happy, then why not?

Absolutely! I am very materialistic and I love being materialistic simply because I am able to enjoy a fantastic quality of life and the perks that coming from living a life of my dreams. That is why I always ensure that I buy the fastest, the latest and the most important tools necessary for my growth, my personal development and my improvement. Its a great life and I love my life! Loy Machedo

No, I don’t consider myself a materialistic person, but to achieve my big Big BIG goal, a natural side effect will be a REALLY large amount of money! And that's perfectly OK ‘cuz here’s what I want to do (its my firm’s mission)— Our MISSION is training 60,000 two-person teams of recent college graduates how to “Get Out of Debt and Save Money(TM).” Each team will train 2,000 American household to do the same. Our GOAL is 120,000,000 by 11/28/20. As a direct result of that work, I’ll earn one point five billion dollars. That's $1,500,000,000 . . . a serious chunk of change . . . not what I’d call pocket money! Is that materialistic? No! It's helping people where they hurt the most! And THATS all I’ve got to say about THAT! RC

I’m generally not materialistic—with two reservations: food and clothing First, I enjoy having a small surfeit of nice clothes. Once I’m financially settled, I’ll certainly spend more money on developing a sizable wardrobe. Second, I don’t like having to budget my weekly grocery shopping. I don’t buy the most expensive foods, but I’m generally less happy when I have to eat on a budget. I follow a specific diet, and eating on that diet isn’t fun when you can’t spend a little extra on quality ingredients. Not sure if eating good food qualifies as “materialistic,” but it certainly isn’t necessary. That’s it though. Beyond that, all I need to be a happy camper is a gym membership (but to a cheap gym), the internet, a laptop, a coffee shop nearby, and a public library to be a happy camper. Oh, and a car of course, but owning a car in the southwest of the USA is a necessity. When I lived in Europe I got along without a vehicle just nicely.

Dictionary meaning of Materialistic - excessively concerned with material possessions; money-oriented. I live alone - Hence my material possessions are a Bed and a mattress,a few utensils to cook and eat,a laptop to connect to Internet and a phone to reach people or for people to reach me along with my shoes and clothing. I am concerned about these - meaning - I think about scenarios where my bed breaks while sleeping or my clothes tear off or my shoes wear out or my 5 year old phone stops working. Back in India - i lived with my mother with TV and music system as additions to other possessions that i mentioned above. I like minimalistic living and hence I am not overly concerned about the material possessions I have. I am willing to let go of these things as I know i can get them back in a while. I have done that earlier. I could do it again. I am money-oriented - In the sense that i was to put my money where my mouth is. I am not big on investments and savings,but whatever i do,I am careful about that. Does this mean I am materialistic ? Definitely, May Be :)

Me? Yes, I am. I am made of matter, and things made of matter are either good for me, or bad for me ; and there are things made of matter that I want to possess and use and keep with me lifelong. Most of these are to do with things I’m passionate about. I couldn’t care much for expensive watches and paintings , but I do like gadgets and bikes and cars, and if I were rich, I’d try to be the Tony Stark for this world. It’s not that I value materialism over everything else - if I a genie offered me 1 wish or to choose between health and wealth , I’d wish for excellent health and fitness before wealth, but if I had 3 wishes …. Of course, one day I’d also love to be able to abandon all these things and live freely - because as some wise man said : “The things that we own, end up owning us.”

Yes, i am. Aren't most of us to some extent? I will date you love you if you are broke, but if you don't plan on changing that and just waste your life away doing nonsense and just plain being a careless spender without thinking of the coming rent being due while I work my ass of to get food and pay for everything, then I will ditch you. I will look for the better paying job, I have desires, i want to be able to buy fruits, I enjoy fruits like mango and making myself fruits smoothies everyday, it's a pleasure I want to keep having. I like to have a nice pc to do my work and enjoy some pastime, I don't wanna give up my shopping trips once every few months. I like shiny things, little decorative stuff, I like to either make them or buy them, I want to have that too. I will not ask for money, I will not date you only because you have money but I will work for money because I like my few pleasures, and i want to keep them. They make me happy in all my troubles. Guess this means that money brings me happiness. I don't care I am what I am.

Yes. Because I believe money can buy happiness. Because I believe money can create satisfaction.  Let me explain. I realize that many people throughout the canvas have different opinions and judgements on this subject. But I truly want to become filthy rich! Why? Because I want to create money and make someone happy by using it. That may come in the form of funding an orphanage, or setting up a dispensary or building a school for education someplace where the concept of books does not exist. Besides the spiritual dimension of the materialistic possession that is money, I want to be filthy rich and create happiness for myself by following my passion. I have a thing for vintage cars and motorcycles so I often observe things that I can buy and restore and sell for good money. Maybe keep something for myself . I wanna travel the world and meet a lot of new people and so I wanna make money in the travel business and trot the globe with many people together. Etc.  Answer based on mere opinion. Picture source: Camera Roll.

I'm indeed materialistic but in a really different way! I divide my material requirements into two categories. One as essential materials (like clothing, books and basic materials which are much required for the daily runs) and other class as accessory materials (fancy watches, play stations, costly mobiles, jewelleries, etc without which our life won't be much affected). So whenever I feel I buying an accessory material, I buy it after achieving something. For example, I bought a limited edition watch of Sonata signed by MS Dhoni after scoring 98.72% in my X class.I bought a silver circlet to wear in my hand ( because my favourite kannada hero Vishnuvardhan wore it) after I got first rank in XI class and a gold chain on my first rank in class XII.I bought a laptop after a decent GPA of 9.76 in my first year engineering and a bike in my final year engineering after getting a job.So, basically whatever accessory materials I possess are mostly the token of my achievements! So my materialistic life has a meaning and I have a reason for most of my possessions. My desire to possess something has always led me to achieve something good!! Cheers!

How materialistic am I? Well, I guess I am more materialistic than some and less materialistic than others... (-: TL/DR: I know, I know, this is not a particularly satisfying answer, but it accurately reflects the relative lack of concern I have about any supposed measure of my own materialism--indeed, it's really not something I think about much--but yet also conveys my honest belief that I am nowhere near the extremes on either end of the spectrum when it comes to materialism (or minimalism for that matter). Stated differently, I am entirely comfortable with the extent of my own materialism. If that is not good enough, then let me state specifically for the record that, on a scale of one to ten, I am a six. (Thanks for the A2A, Habib Fanny, and based on your own answer to this question, I suspect that you, too, might also be a six...welcome to the middle!)

No. Otherwise I would have been very wealthy by now. I don’t care enough, I guess. Money and stuff is fun to use in life, but for me it can never be the sole focus of life. I need just enough to buy food and clothes. And the basic stuff needed in a house. If you have morej than five times that basic possession level, you’ll constantly worry about some crook coming ’round to steal it from you. You understand what I’m saying? Even in material things moderation is king.

I googled materialistic and it was defined so : “excessively concerned with material possessions; money-oriented.” I am materialistic by second definition, i love money. I see it as a single language that speaks to people speaking different languages. There is not a single material thing that can make 99.99% people happy - except for some extra money. At the same time, i hate material possessions and do not think that they can bring happiness. And am minimalist in terms of possessions. I think hearing giggle of my 1.5 year old niece can bring 1000x more happiness than getting new iPhone. But poor people rarely get to giggle.

Just look at my bio. Material things don’t matter to me. I have been that way from day one. I get excited when someone gives me a new pen. What do we really need in life? Food, shelter,clothing,health. To give and receive love. When you really get down to it, material things really don’t matter. As my dad often said You come into this world with nothing and you leave with nothing.

Not very. I prefer minimalism. I like creating things but dislike crafting because after I craft, I have a craft…lol. I do like space and the idea of the security of home ownership. I like things that make my life easier like a car that runs well and a washer/dryer and computer with printer. Those types of things. I don’t wear jewelry and I tend to wear a sort of uniform in terms of clothing. Very comfy but similar items in simple colors. I hate knickknacks and that sort of thing, I love experiences and travel. I like to be with good friends. I own very little outside of necessities.

author_info.name: Iván J. Andrade (イヴァンあんどらで)

response.answer_text: Yeah but not 100% materialistic. I do care about money, and I think money is one of the most important things in the world. However, there are some things that go above money in my opinion. I place my family above money.I place my friends above moneyI place mine and my family’s health above money.Health is directly related to money but it’s slightly above ’‘the green ones” In conclusion: Money matters, money makes the world go round, money allows you to have many luxuries. But money isn’t THE most important necessity. Can you buy real love with money? Can you buy real family with money? Nuff said.

Oh yes, 100%. My life goal is to die a millionaire, and give my children and parents a good life. Otherwise how am I gonna afford that big house with a swimming pool and and a garage attached? Love does not pay for things, $$ does. And brother, everything is material on earth, I cannot live a comfortable life by just meditating in the Himalayas, I’d probably be happier in an S-Class.

Materialism is crap for me. I am a 16 year old teen whose clothes betray him every now and then. My father is a post-grad of economics. So naturally cost planning is embedded to my thought process.I don't make too extravagant demands from my parents. I prefer clothes that can be worn rather than to show off.I have no taste for aesthetic and gourmet food. Burger King and KFC are for special occasions so I just prefer street food.I am no HYPEBEAST. I buy shoes which are affordable for me (cost planning genes). All these overpriced and hyped brands are beyond my budget.I always try to bargain for things which I don't even need. I don't plan anything specific before buying. I always buy things which have worth to me.Bargaining enables me to satiate my materialism and considerably reduce my overall expenses.I am a teenager and I also have an inferiority complex. I feel jealous when other children use branded goods but I calm myself saying that all things are achieving the same purpose . So just sit back and relax because you have nothing to lose.

Materialistic by heart. Intellectual by choice. If someone took everything from me you won't see me smiling though, who in their right mind smiles when you take everything from them. xP Wait! Did I mention I like luxurious lifestyle? P.S: Above attached image is just to distract you guys from the real me. I like to be materialistic but cannot afford to. *Monkey with the closed eye emoticon* Pic source: Pinterest

Any earning member of a family has to be materialistic, otherwise they cannot survive and also support their family.But it is the question of how they acquire, utilize and exhibit their possessions that defines their materialistic attitude.If they have more than what they need, they are typically materialistic.If they have just what is required they have won over their greed and desire and live a satisfied and contended life.If they have bare minimum requirements and donate their materialistic possessions they are getting towards eternal happiness. They have won over materialism.As regards me, I am a pure materialistic person. I earn for a family and at the same time try to save for the future. As I am in the fifties I have the fear of limited years of active service. I probably want to earn more during this period and hence an order of magnitude more materialistic than a young person!

No!!, I am Actually Minimalist! Two years back when I was 16, I used to argue with my parents for New Clothes and Gadgets. My desires were clung to Materialistic things such as stylish Clothes, Cool Gadgets and Bikes. But now the time has showered some good luck over me and made me a Minimalist. When I pack my bags for my college, all my clothes get into a College-Sack! Only two pairs of casual shirt-pant is what I need. I never buy any useless stuff like expensive Deodorants, Hair Cream. And with this all I feel contained like never before.  Image-Source: Minimalist Vector Image

When I was richer, I bought the computer I wanted…. a Mac Mini. I needed a new monitor, a DVD player and a scanner, so I bought them too. My old printer still worked, so I kept it. I’ve got most of the books, CDs and DVDs I want. I have no interest in a car. I have no interest in moving to a new place. I have enough. My wife would like a little more money, so I’m working so she can have enough. I guess that is about as far as my materialism goes. I’m not interested in fancy clothes, but I’d like to go to a nice restaurant now and again. I also wouldn’t mind traveling. But I can live without it.

Yes, I don’t know why but I have always imbued objects with meaning, especially things that were gifts from friends and family. I look at our dining room table and I don’t see an antique mahogany table, I see my mother’s table, something she chose, that we sat around and dressed for dinner parties. Objects are full of memory for me, which maybe is why I have a poor memory myself, I rely on the memories evoked by the things in my life, or maybe I do it because I have a poor memory. I couldn’t understand when my mother died why everyone just wanted to throw out her stuff, or send it to the auction house which is close to the same thing. So I have most of it.

I'm going to quote Tyler Durden of the film “Fight Club”: “The things we own end up owning us”. I'm a Quaker. One of the tenets we live by is “a life of simplicity freely chosen is a source of strength”. I live on a boat. Everything I own is on it. Space is as an absolute premium, so I have to think twice before I buy something. “Where's it going to go? What must leave so this can enter?” The boat is a physical constraint but it's also a useful tool for a freely chosen spiritual restraint. I'm an environmentalist. Everything we buy has to come from somewhere, and eventually go somewhere. As large as the world is, it's finite, and we're gobbling it up at an unsustainable rate. And finally, I'm secure enough that I don't need to show others that I've “made the grade” by a visible display of what I have. The thoughts I have and the friendships I have are worth more to me than any thing, and my life choices reflect that.

No. I ain't materialistic. I don't waste money, so I haven't re-recharged my Jio yet. Instead I use my neighbour's WiFi.I believe in personal time. I sleep on a 6 inch thin mattress with white pillows.I believe being clean. So I prefer traveling by car to avoid sweating in Auto or ST bus.I believe that outer environment affects the inner you. So my car is always chilled.I believe in sharing. So I eat my sister's chocolates and her share of any sweet.I also believe in listening ‘gud mugik', so I have Philips headphones with good bass.Infact I am thinking of moving to a Private Island with a yacht for complete peace.
Nope, not a bit. When I have extra money at all it always goes to my little kid and my cats. I dont wear any jewelry at all and my favorite place to shop is Goodwill. I love that place.

I remember an instance of 2013. It was few days before Ardh Kumbh, when we ( me and my friends) went to Sangam. There were pandals of different babas. We went inside that one pompous pandal.( The pandal was like a kings courtroom for people to sit) The Baba was yet to come. I heard from his disciples that he is at some place 2km away from pandal and will arrive shortly. Thinking of a Baba as a simple figure. We thought he might be coming on foot. But whoop an Audi came in 5 minutes.Our Jaws dropped and our expressions changed. Then was the time for his pravachan (preachings). Baba- Live simple, everything in the world will die. Don't go for wordly pleasures, just pray to God and devote yourself to god. Satisfaction with small things, less thing is the way of life.( I shortened the speech of half hour, but these were the main highlights.) Then my eyes went to the rollex watch and branded chappals he was wearing. His round full tummy which told a total different story. I concluded something “ Live simple with small Audi, small rollex and a few billions of dollars. Don't be greedy. Be ascetic”
Not really. Usually, everything has a cost. And the cost is more than just money
Okay…so let's have a look:  Ummm….well, I no longer think I'm materialistic! Peace.

Barely at all. I actually just wrote an answer about this yesterday, about how it baffles me how people purchase items that they don’t need. It’s genuinely outside of my realm of understanding. I’m a ruthless pragmatist (which I attribute to/blame on my academic background in economics). If a product, over the life cycle of its existence, gives me more benefit than it costs, then I purchase it. If not, I don’t. It’s as simple as that.

Am I materialistic? . . Well me being a humble human of the 21st century need certain things to survive…. .  My phone..! .  My laptop..! .  A fan… ( … Well cause it's really hot here.…) .  Some more fans…. (..I can dream can't I?…) .  A temple in my name…. (…*grins*…) .  Well…. (…who dosen't?…) .  A bed… (…no it's not connected to the previous image..no… *winks*..) . I am. Very. And I am proud of being one. I just don't know if you're using the word 'materialistic' in the negative light or not in your question. Anyway, it does not matter. We all die anyway. I understand and appreciate my spiritual nature, too. Actually, being materialistic and spiritual are just 2 facets of my being human. That's fabulous. That's enough for now.

No. Everything is the property of the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Krishna [Bhagavad Gita 10.8] And when used in His service, for His pleasure nothing remain material. Everything is spiritualized. [Reference : (Bhakti-rasämrita-sindhu 1.2.255)] If you wish to learn the art of living life full of unwavering satisfaction [Reference : Bhagavad Gita 6.20] And filled with extreme happiness… [Bhagavad Gita 9.2].. Then.. I recommend the book Bhagavad gita As It Is , commentary by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada. [Available free to read online] Thank you very much for your question.

Not enough. You see, the real problem is not that people are too materialist, it's that they are not materialist enough. People don't buy stuff they don't need for the sake of owning them, they do it to impress others. Thorsten Veblen called it ostentatious consumption. This is not materialism, it's symbolism. People are not buying cars, they are buying a way of life, they are not buying clothes, they are “expressing themselves”. Most of the stuff we have don't fulfill a purely materialistic value. Your house doesn't just shelter you, it projects your personal branding and shows off your earning abilities. They are not tangible things. That's why we consume too much and why we are not materialistic enough.

Of course I am. Just a month ago, I bought an iPhone X. This month, I bought a new pair of glasses; the frame is Oakley. Next year, I am planning to get either An iMac + iPad Pro (with Pencil) orA Macbook ProProbably a few more Doctor Who t-shirts as well.

Very much. I want to live in a nice house and wear bespoke suits made by my tailor and custom made shoes from a shoemaker. I also fancy expensive vacations in nice hotels and food in noble restaurants. Just to add one meta-reflection to all the subjective characterisations in this thread: “Anti-materialism” in our times is ironically the ideology of the upper classes who want to appear as righteous stoics next to all those prolish, consume-oriented brutes.

I use materials and tools that aide my survival. And to get access or use these materials I must find a way to make money. That’s the model human beings have designed for sustenance. So when someone is a participant in the economy then how can they not be materialistic!? The real question should have been: Do you prefer materialism? And the answer to that would be a big NO!
I think I’m very interested in money… Not for me though, but for my family. I need my people to have what they need, for myself I’m happy with little…

I will be super honest. My biggest dream is to spent everything i earn. But trust me Guys when i say i want to spent it means i wanna buy all sort of comfortness to me . I dont know if it makes me materialistic or not. Thanks Cheers ✌
No , I am first Emotional then somewhat Intellectual . That's why I am here answering your questions on QUORA without any materialistic gain whatsoever.

Yes everyone is. Materialism is all about Desire. Even the most spiritual ones have desires ,it's just the name of that desire is MOKSHA. But, after all ,it's too a desire only and till the time desire exists,materialism will co-exist. You can get rid of that,only with Death.
Outer world is materialistic. For success in the outer world then our should think materialistic, so do I think.
Not at all…
Yes, or why else would I bust my ass every day & eat ramen noodles on Christmas eve, new year’s eve, chinese new year’s eve?
Pretty much, as opposed to idealistic or dualistic. I live in in physical world.
